Travel.name: 旅行
Travel.text:
The rules in the “Exploration” section in the Player’s Handbook cover the basics of travel on a scale ranging from minutes to days. The tools in this section can add excitement to a longer trek.

Journeys without Destinations

Sometimes, characters travel without a clear path to follow or a clear destination in mind. In such a case, use the grid of your map (squares or hexes) to define the stages of the journey, however many miles each square or hex might be. (This style of play is sometimes called “hex crawling.”)

In this kind of wilderness exploration, you can take one of two approaches to travel challenges:

Sandbox Approach. Your map of the area determines what characters find when they enter any particular hex on the map. You might have encounters or obstacles in place for every hex, or they could be spread farther apart.

Random Approach. Use tables to randomly determine encounters or obstacles in each hex the characters enter.

Whichever approach you use, running a journey otherwise works the same as described in the rest of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningExplor.JournalEntryPage.QrGAynDfEKmKX14L]{Travel} section.

Journey Stages

It can be helpful to break up a journey into stages, with each stage representing anything from a few hours’ journey to ten days or so of travel. A journey might have only a single stage if the trip is a matter of following a clear path to a well-known destination. A journey consisting of three stages makes for a satisfying trek. For example, the characters might travel along a river to the forest’s edge (stage 1), follow a trail into the heart of the woods (stage 2), and then search the woods for an ancient ruin (stage 3). A long journey might involve even more stages and occupy several game sessions.

You decide how to break up the journey, though your decision can be shaped by the characters’ plan for navigating the journey. When the characters know the route they must take, the stages of the journey should correspond to the way you might give someone directions, as in the example above.

Planning the Stages. You can use the accompanying @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgTrackingSheet]{Travel Planner} sheet to plan the stages of a journey. (Use multiple copies of the Travel Planner for a journey with more than three stages.)

For each stage, note where it starts and ends, the distance covered, and the predominant terrain. Choose or randomly determine the weather on that stage (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningExplor.JournalEntryPage.52a3vRwhCNY60oEZ]{Weather} later in this chapter). Plan one or more challenges for each stage, such as an encounter, an obstacle, a search for something hidden, or a chance of getting lost, as described under @UUID[.HtzmbDmbBmFB2gDq#journey-stage-challenges]{Journey Stage Challenges}.

Planning in Stages

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgTrackingSheet.JournalEntryPage.9gW8NWa2ETg8tO9V]{Travel Planner} page is designed to represent a single stage of travel. You can drag additional copies from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgTrackingSheet]{Tracking Sheets} journal for each stage of your journey.

Running the Stages. For each stage of the journey, follow these steps in order:

Step 1: Set the Pace. Have the players choose their group’s travel pace for the stage: Slow, Normal, or Fast (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningExplor.JournalEntryPage.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Pace}). Based on the length of the stage (in miles) and the group’s pace, determine how long this stage takes to complete.

Step 2: Narrate the Travel. Describe what happens as the characters complete this stage of their journey. Introduce and resolve any challenges (see @UUID[.HtzmbDmbBmFB2gDq#journey-stage-challenges]{Journey Stage Challenges}).

Step 3: Track Food and Water Consumption. Each creature in the party expends the appropriate amount of food and water for the length of the stage. If the party lacks enough food or water, the characters risk dehydration and malnutrition.

Step 4: Track Progress. Track the party’s progress at the end of the stage. You might mark their position on a map of the region and note the elapsed time on the Travel Planner.

Depending on how you planned the stages, the end of a stage might mean the characters arrive at a landmark, a waystation, or an adventure location, whether or not it’s their final destination.

Narration During Travel.name: 旅行中的叙述
Narration During Travel.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh2ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.8GvM65QMaaa8tkTy]

Just as movies use travel montages to convey long and arduous journeys in a matter of seconds, you can use a few sentences of descriptive text to paint a picture of a journey in your players’ minds before moving on. Describe the journey as vividly as you like, but keep momentum by focusing on the most notable details that reinforce the desired mood.

Visual aids can help set the scene for the characters’ travels. Image searches on the internet can lead you to breathtaking landscapes (in fact, that’s a good phrase to search for). You can spice up your descriptions with truly fantastical elements. For example, a forest might be home to tiny dragonets instead of birds, or its trees might be festooned with giant webs or have eerie green, glowing sap. A single fantastic element within an otherwise realistic and memorable landscape is enough.

Use the landscape to set the mood and tone for your adventure. In one forest, close-set trees might shroud all light and seem to watch the adventurers as they pass. In another, sunlight streams through the leaves above, and flower-laden vines twine up every trunk. Signs of corruption—rotting wood, foul-smelling water, and rocks covered with slimy moss—can be a signal that the adventurers are drawing close to the site of evil power that is their destination or can provide clues to the nature of the threats to be found there.

Do Players Need to Track Rations?

You might decide that tracking Rations is unnecessary in your game. Even if the characters are in a desert, you can assume that a character with proficiency in the Survival skill can find enough food and water to sustain the party. Make sure you work that into your narration of the journey so the player feels good about choosing that skill proficiency. You can also assume the characters can load their mounts with enough Rations for their journey, or they can use magic (such as the Create Food and Water spell) to sustain them.

On the other hand, having players track Rations seems appropriate for a more realistic campaign. Characters in such a campaign should approach a long wilderness journey as a challenge in logistics: how many pack animals do they need to carry the food for the journey, and how do they feed the animals?

As always, communicate your expectations about these rules to the players ahead of time. If you don’t plan on tracking Rations, tell your players that before they spend an hour purchasing supplies for their journey.

Journey Stage Challenges

Challenges that adventurers might face during a journey stage include the following, which are discussed in the sections that follow:

  • Encounters with other creatures
  • Foraging
  • Navigation (and becoming lost)
  • Obstacles
  • Searches
  • Tracking

Encounters with Other Creatures. The Encounter Distance column in the @UUID[.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Terrain} table gives the range at which creatures might become aware of each other while journeying through the wilderness. When staging an encounter, consider these possibilities:

Ambush. Monsters set up an ambush along a route they expect travelers to follow.

Attack from Above. Flying monsters swoop down to attack the characters.

Distant Sighting. The characters and monsters spot each other from a distance in open terrain.

Found by Chance. The characters happen upon monsters that are camping, eating, hunting, basking in the sun, walking along the same trail, or engaged in some other activity.

Pursuit. The characters are tracking monsters, or the monsters are tracking them. The encounter begins when the two groups get close enough to interact.

Foraging. Characters without water and Rations can stave off dehydration and malnutrition by gathering food and water as they travel. A foraging character makes a [[/skill sur]] check once per journey stage (or once per day if a stage is shorter than a day). The DC is determined by the abundance of food and water in the region, as shown in the Foraging DC column of the @UUID[.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Terrain table}. If multiple characters forage, each character makes a separate check.

A foraging character finds nothing on a failed check. On a successful check, roll [[/r 1d6]] and add the character’s Wisdom modifier to determine how much food (in pounds) the character finds per day of the journey stage, then repeat the roll for water (in gallons).

Navigation. If the characters aren’t following an established path or traveling with a landmark in sight, they risk getting lost. Here are some circumstances that can cause a group to lose its way:

  • Branching passages underground
  • Horizon-obscuring terrain, such as dense forest
  • Obscuring weather, such as heavy rain or fog
  • Traveling at night
  • Traveling at sea while unable to see the sky or any familiar land

Let the players know when the characters are at risk of getting lost, then have the characters choose one of their number to make a [[/skill sur]] check against a DC appropriate to the terrain, as shown in the Navigation DC column of the @UUID[.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Terrain table}. Another member of the group can take the Help action to assist this check as normal.

If the check fails, the party goes off course. You decide what this looks like: they might follow the wrong branch of a river, orient themselves to the wrong mountain peak on the horizon, or get turned around in the forest. As a baseline, assume that getting lost extends the length of the current journey stage by 1d6 × 10 percent. It might also affect subsequent stages of the journey.

Obstacles. An obstacle is terrain or weather that obstructs the characters’ path. Examples include a cliff, a blizzard, or a forest fire. To get past the obstacle, characters might need to backtrack and find an alternate route, or they might need to take shelter until the obstacle goes away. Let the players spend time thinking about a solution, then be generous in adjudicating whether their plan works.

In addition to the chance of a delay (adding a few hours, a day, or a couple of days to the current stage of the journey), here are some other consequences you can impose if characters fail to overcome or bypass an obstacle:

Combat Encounter. The characters encounter one or more Hostile creatures. For example, marching through a burning forest instead of circling around it might prompt an encounter with raging fire elementals.

Damage. The characters take damage. For example, a character who tumbles over a waterfall might take Bludgeoning damage. See @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgResolvingOutc.JournalEntryPage.YThtWUSw1VjY1cY6]{Improvising Damage} in this chapter for guidelines on determining how much damage is appropriate.

Exhaustion. The obstacle fatigues the characters, causing them to gain Exhaustion levels. For example, marching through a blizzard instead of taking shelter might cause each character to gain [[/r 1d4]] Exhaustion levels.

Another Condition. The obstacle imposes another condition on the characters. For example, wading through a fetid swamp rather than skirting around it might impose the &Reference[Poisoned apply=false] condition, which lasts until removed by magic.

Searches. This challenge often comes up in the last stage of a journey: the characters have to find their destination, which might be an island, an old mine, an ancient ruin, a magical pool, a hag’s cottage, or some other feature.

The Search DC column of the @UUID[.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Terrain} table suggests DCs for [[/skill prc]] checks made to find something in different types of terrain. You can adjust these DCs based on the specific terrain features and the nature of what the characters are trying to find, using the guidelines for setting DCs earlier in this chapter.

Tracking. A specific instance of searching on a journey is when adventurers choose their path by following the tracks of other creatures. To track, one or more trackers must succeed on a [[/skill sur]] check. You might require trackers to make a new check in any of the following circumstances:

Resting. The trackers resume tracking after finishing a Short or Long Rest.

Shifting Weather or Terrain. The weather or terrain changes in a way that makes tracking harder.

Terrain Obstacle. The trail crosses a river or similar obstacle that allows no tracks.

The DC for the check depends on how well the ground shows signs of a creature’s passage. No roll is necessary in situations where the tracks are obvious, such as following an army along a muddy road. Spotting tracks on bare rock is more challenging unless the creature being tracked leaves a distinct trail. Additionally, the passage of time often makes tracks harder to follow. In a situation where there is no trail to follow, you can rule that tracking is impossible.

Use the Search DC column of the @UUID[.j8aPJPiRHIGUSWHz]{Travel Terrain} table as a starting point for setting the DC for tracking. If you prefer, you can choose a DC based on your assessment of the difficulty—higher if days have elapsed since the creature passed, lower if the creature is leaving an obvious trail such as blood. You can also grant Advantage on the check if there’s more than one set of tracks to follow or Disadvantage if the trail passes through a busy area.

On a failed check, the character loses the trail but can attempt to find it again by carefully searching the area. It takes 10 minutes to find a trail in a confined area, such as a series of caverns, or 1 hour outdoors.

Travel Pace.name: 旅行步调
Travel Pace.text:
根据 玩家手册中的描述，角色们的团队可以以快速、中速或慢速步调进行陆路旅行。在任何旅程阶段，主要地形决定了角色的最快旅行步调，如旅行地形表中的最快步调列所示。某些具体因素可以影响团队的旅行步调。

路况良好。 出现状态良好的道路时，可以使团队的最快步调提高一节（从慢速到中速或从中速到快速）。

速度更慢的旅客。 如果任何一位成员的速度降低到正常速度的一半以下，那么整个团队必须以慢速步调前进。

延长旅行。 在疲劳的风险下，角色可以每天坚持旅行超过8小时。在8小时旅行之外，每额外旅行一小时后，角色必须通过一次 [[/save con]] 豁免，否则将增加1级力竭。DC为10+额外旅行的小时数。

特殊移动。 如果一个团队能够长时间以高速移动，例如使用“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplWindWalk00] 法术或 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.equipment.Item.dmgCarpetOfFlyin]魔法物品，则使用以下规则将团队的速度转换为旅行速率：

英里/小时 = 速度 ÷ 10

英里/天 （中速步调）=英里/小时
× 旅行小时数（通常为8）

快速步调 =英里/天 × 1⅓（向下取整）

慢速步调 =英里/天 × ⅔（向下取整）

如果角色正在飞行或他们的特殊移动方式允许他们无视 &Reference[Difficult Terrain], ，则无论地形如何，他们都可以用快速步调移动。

载具。 乘坐载具旅行的角色使用载具速度并以英里/小时来决定旅行速率（如 玩家手册 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbEquipment0000] 所示），并且不选择旅行步调。

Weather.name: 天气
Weather.text:
在角色的旅程的每个阶段，你都可以通过投掷天气表来确定天气情况，并根据地形和季节进行适当调整。投掷三次 [[/r 1d20]] 来确定温度、风力和降雨量。

天气在大多数情况下对游戏没有显著影响，但请见第三章“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgDmsToolbox000.JournalEntryPage.xgLA30rErlkjIPAK] ”了解极端天气的影响。在描述角色的旅程时加入天气细节，可以让游戏更加令人印象深刻。

Introduction.name: 简介
Introduction.text:
在交涉中，冒险者们通常都具有一个目的，比如想获取信息、获得援助、赢得他人信任、逃避惩罚、避免战斗、洽谈条约或实现其他目标。成功完成遭遇则意味着达成目的。

有些DM将交涉视为一种形式自由的角色扮演机会，而骰子很少在游戏中发挥作用；另外一些DM也会通过让角色进行一些魅力检定来解决问题。大多数游戏则介于两者之间，于角色扮演和偶尔的属性检定之间找到平衡。

Roleplaying.name: 角色扮演
Roleplaying.text:
用角色扮演来创造戏剧效果或幽默桥段不需要你成为专业演员或谐星。关键是要注意那些会让你的玩家哄堂大笑或产生情感共鸣的故事元素和角色特征，并将这些内容融入进你的角色扮演中。

NPC的人物刻画

在思考如何扮演NPC或怪物时，请考虑使用一到两个最能描述该生物的形容词。了解该生物的阵营也有助于人物刻画。于写手的一个经典建议是：展示，而非陈述。例如，与其陈述这个NPC具有风趣而诚实的特点，不如让NPC经常说双关语，并随口分享些私人趣闻。

你可以通过以下方式来进一步提升对某个生物的刻画：

运用面部表情。 你的面部表情有助于传达生物的情感：微笑，皱眉，怒吼，打哈欠或撅嘴，视情况而定。

运用动作和姿势。 动作和姿势有助于展现NPC的性格。你可以通过翻白眼和手指按摩太阳穴来反映一位大法师的不满；垂着头，不时偷瞄玩家会展现一种顺从或恐惧的感觉；昂首挺胸可以展现自信。

运用声音。 改变你声音的音量，并借用现实生活、电影或电视中的说话方式让NPC与众不同。

让玩家参与其中

虽然有些玩家比其他人更享受角色扮演，但交涉有助于让所有玩家都沉浸在游戏中。考虑采用以下方法，来让强互动性的游戏回能吸引各种口味的玩家。

迎合玩家偏好。 喜欢扮演的玩家（见本章 "@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.tiekOc44JRTfFZgS]"）以交涉为乐趣所在，那么就让他们成为焦点，并以身作则来激励其他玩家吧！不过，也请确保要去调整交涉的各个方面来迎合其他玩家的口味。

让特定角色参与进来。 如果有玩家不怎么乐意参与进交涉中，你则可以创造为他们的角色量身定制的场合。也许相关NPC是某个冒险者的家人或联系人，且将注意力都放在了他身上。有些NPC可能会特别关注那些他们感觉亲近的角色。

如果只有某几个玩家主要在交涉中说话，那就花点时间和其他人互动。你可以让NPC 指名道姓另一个角色：“那么这位大块头朋友呢？你打算用什么来换取我的青睐？" 如果玩家不太适应角色扮演，你可以要求他们描述自己角色在对话中的行为从而让他们参与进来。

使用其他属性值。 考虑以下的其他可能性，让那些魅力并非强项的角色有机会大显身手：

力量。 在其中一人同意进行掰手腕比赛之前，NPC 不愿意和角色们说话；或者一个强壮的角色需要用肉体去防范NPC逃跑。

敏捷。 NPC与入侵者敌对，因此角色必须从隐匿处说话；或者用交涉来分散角色的注意力，让角色可以接近 NPC并从他的口袋里偷些东西。

智力。 NPC 的话语里充满了对某一特定知识领域的晦涩典故，以至于角色无法使用所获得的信息直到从中解读出这些晦涩的真相；或者NPC 拒绝给出直接回答，而是含糊其辞，角色必须东拼西凑来获得他们要找的信息。

感知。 一位NPC隐藏着重要的信息，角色们必须读懂他的在语言之外的留下的线索，才能分辨出哪些是真话，哪些在扯谎；或者关键信息隐藏在互动发生地的房间细节中，而敏锐的角色可能会注意到。

Attitude.name: 态度
Attitude.text:
DM控制的每个生物有以下三种对冒险者的态度：友好、冷漠或敌对。第 4 章的“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgPlanEncounter.JournalEntryPage.Qa7LIRWcz3vC9lVb]”部分提供帮助你确定生物的初始态度的指南。

角色可以通过言行改变生物的态度。例如，为一群态度为冷漠的矿工买饮料可能会让他们态度变为友好。当态度发生变化时，请向玩家描述。例如，矿工可能会通过提供一些有用的信息、许诺日后报答善意、或邀请角色加入一场饮酒友谊赛来体现他们刚刚建立的友好关系。

交涉中的属性检定

你可以决定属性检定会有多大程度上影响交涉的结果。一次简单的交涉可能只涉及简短的对话和一次魅力检定，而一次更复杂的遭遇可能需要多次属性检定来帮助引导对话的走向。

使用协助动作

当一个角色使用协助动作来协助另一个角色影响一个NPC或怪物时，鼓励进行协助角色的玩家参与对话，或至少描述一下他们的角色为了协助另一个角色取得成功正在做什么或说什么。

Know Your Players.name: 了解你的玩家
Know Your Players.text:
玩家的任务是创造角色（战役的主人公），赋予他们生命，并通过他们的行动来推进游戏的进程。而身为地下城主，你的任务是让玩家们沉浸在你创造的世界之中，并让其角色有机会去做出壮举。

了解玩家最喜欢D&D游戏的哪些方面，将有助于你去创造和运作能让他们享受并铭记许久的冒险。只要你知道团队中的每个玩家都喜欢下列哪些活动，你就可以根据玩家的喜好来量身定制冒险。

一桌兴趣相投的玩家非常难得。即使某些遭遇不符合每个人的喜好，但只要拥有找到其平衡点的诀窍，也能让他们都能从各个游戏回中获得乐趣。最好的情况下，玩家们就如他们的角色一般，拥有不同的兴趣和能力，能够应对各种挑战。

表演

享受表演的玩家会喜欢去展现他们角色的个性，观点与态度。在游玩时，他们可能会打扮起来或使用他们角色的声音。他们热衷于与NPC，怪物以及小队成员们的交涉。

通过以下方法让喜欢表演的玩家融入其中：

  • 给予他们更多能发展角色个性与背景的机会。
  • 允许他们经常与NPC们互动。
  • 突出强调战斗遭遇中的角色扮演元素。
  • 将角色背景故事中的元素融入到你的冒险中。

探索

渴望探索的玩家们会想去体验幻想世界能够带来的奇妙之处。他们想去知晓那个角落或是那座山头周围有什么，并热衷于寻找隐藏的线索与宝藏。

通过以下方法让喜欢探索的玩家融入其中：

  • 给出一些能暗示将要发生之事的线索。
  • 当他们花时间探索时，让他们能有所收获。
  • 在令人兴奋的环境中使用生动的描述，并使用有趣的地图和道具。
  • 给出关于怪物的秘闻让他们发掘，或文化上的细节供他们学习。

战斗

享受奇幻战斗的玩家会喜欢对战恶人与怪物时的刺激感。以战斗为最优解的情况最对他们的胃口，比起谈判和调查，他们更倾向于大胆的行动。

通过以下方法让喜欢战斗的玩家融入其中：

  • 开启一场突发的战斗遭遇。
  • 生动地描写角色们通过攻击与法术造成的破坏与结果。
  • 让战斗遭遇中包含大量的弱小怪物。

推进

喜欢推进的玩家急于看见事情发生进展，即使这意味着承受严峻的风险。比起小心谨慎地策划行动，他们更愿意以身试险并直面后果。

通过以下方法让喜欢推进的玩家融入其中：

  • 让他们能够对周遭环境产生影响。
  • 在你的冒险中加入能够勾起他们兴趣的事物。
  • 让其行为使角色们陷入危难之中。
  • 让遭遇中的NPC与玩家们同样活跃且难以捉摸。

优化

享受优化角色能力的玩家喜欢通过获得等级，新特性和魔法物品来微调他们的角色，使其发挥最佳的表现。他们欢迎任何能够展示其角色卓越性能的机会。

通过以下方法让喜欢优化的玩家融入其中：

  • 用他们渴望的魔法物品作为冒险的引子和奖励。
  • 加入些能让他们用上其角色的超凡能力的遭遇。
  • 为非战斗遭遇提供可量化的奖励，例如经验值。

解决难题

想要解决难题的玩家们喜欢仔细研究NPC动机，解开恶人的阴谋诡计，破解谜题和制定计划。

通过以下方法让喜欢解决难题的玩家融入其中：

  • 加入需要思考的谜题和棘手情况。
  • 用游戏内的收益来奖励计划和战略。
  • 创造拥有复杂动机的NPC们。

社交

许多团队都包括了那些比起实际投入进某个游戏部分，更主要为享受社交活动，并想要和朋友消磨时间的玩家。这些玩家想要加入游戏，但他们并不倾向去关心冒险的沉浸感，反而更没什么主见，不怎么投入进游戏、规则或故事的细节中。牢记不要试图强迫这些玩家投入进他们不想投入的内容。

讲故事

喜爱讲故事的玩家会想去为游戏叙事做出贡献。他们喜欢看见他们的角色能够深深牵扯进正在开展的故事，且乐于看见和总体故事息息相关，甚至能扩充其内容的遭遇。

通过以下方法让喜欢讲故事的玩家融入其中：

  • 利用角色的背景故事来塑造战役的情节。
  • 确保每个遭遇都能推动故事的发展。
  • 让他们的角色引导未来事件的走向。
  • 把能让冒险者们发掘出新冒险机会的个性与牵绊赋予NPC们。
  • 包含一些可以反映出冒险者们先前决策的桥段。

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh2ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.Qyxu98T7fwJ6JzQn]

Group Size.name: 团队规模
Group Size.text: D&D的规则与出版的冒险通常预设了 4 到 6 名玩家以及DM。以下建议可以帮助你把冒险应用在更小或更大的团队中。

Small Groups.name: 小型团队
Small Groups.text:
人数小于 4 位玩家的团队可能会在战斗遭遇中碰到困难，尤其是缺乏了某些重要职能的小队（例如一个穿着护甲，与敌人正面交锋的角色，或是可以施展治疗法术保证全队生存的角色）。你可以通过减少战斗遭遇中的敌人数量，或是给予小队所需资源，例如 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.equipment.Item.dmgPotionOfHeali] 来弥补。

你也可以添加小队成员，如下文所述。

DM操控的冒险者

你可以创建一位属于你的冒险者角色（有时被称作“DMPC”-地下城主玩家角色）来陪伴队伍。当你的朋友正在探索你的世界时，这是一种能让你与他们一同扮演的有益方式，但请记住你必须在战斗中也使用这名NPC。

确保玩家的角色们始终为游戏的焦点，且不要让你的角色为整个团队做决策，这会导致你剥夺了玩家们的主动权。

NPC队伍成员

你可以把非玩家角色（NPC）加入冒险队伍中。使用 怪物图鉴 中的NPC数据卡来表现这些配角。如果你不想自己运作这些NPC，则邀请一个或多个玩家，让他们把NPC视为第二角色。这些NPC可能是冒险者们的雇员或学徒，所以由主要角色们带头进行探索和社交活动合情合理，NPC们则淡入幕后。

更多信息见第三章中“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgDmsToolbox000.JournalEntryPage.5GOEEHaai1dsSxbx]”。

使用多个角色的玩家

一或多名玩家可以分别扮演两个角色。同时运作两个角色是个挑战，所以请确保这些玩家能够接受使用多个角色进行游戏。

这个方法最适合在专注于战斗的游戏中使用，因为这可以把适合战斗的角色们填充进队伍中。一位玩家同时扮演两位角色会很困难。你可以建议玩家专注于扮演一个角色，并让另外的角色降为配角。

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh2ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.0QOrTJjosMDU60SX]

Large Groups.name: 大型团队
Large Groups.text:
对于大型团队来说，最主要的顾虑是如何保持桌上的秩序以及如何不让战斗过于缓慢。

队长

考虑让玩家们指定一名队长，并只让他一人告诉你队伍的行动。与团队的其他成员一同讨论出队伍行动的共识将成为队长的职责。

加速战斗

慷慨提供情报。 如果你把对手们的护甲等级告知玩家，则可以减少一次攻击结算间所需的交互步骤。与其告诉你数值并询问是否击中，玩家可以更简单地告诉你攻击命中与否且造成多少点伤害，或许还能锦上添花地加上些描写（见本章后文“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningCombat.JournalEntryPage.V1W6co6loHKoxVEZ]”）。同样地，如果你知道每个角色的AC，你也不需要去询问怪物的攻击命中与否。

帮助玩家跟上节奏。 如果一位玩家不确定要在其战斗回合中做些什么，你可以为他简要回顾一下战况以帮助玩家决定。还有多少敌人仍旧坚挺，他们看起来伤势如何？于那个角色眼前最直接的威胁是什么？

让先攻显而易见。 向你的玩家们展示先攻顺序，以便于让他们互相了解他们角色的回合何时到来，并可以提前思考他们的角色在下一回合的行动。使用先攻值（见本章“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningCombat]」）- 或许也可以让玩家以先攻顺序重排座位-将在大型团队中有所帮助。

多扔骰子。 鼓励玩家们同时扔出攻击检定和伤害掷骰。你也可以这么做。

战斗追踪器能加快游戏节奏

战斗追踪器对您的玩家可见，它会显示行动顺序，这样每个人都能知道自己的回合何时到来。

DM 还能按住 图标，然后配置一个 "追踪资源" 比如护甲等级 ("attributes.ac.value")，这样就能向您（但不会向您的玩家）展示战斗追踪器中每个角色的护甲等级。

使用回合式结构

如果你发现个别玩家很难获得在探索或交涉中发挥的机会，那么可以让角色们投掷先攻并以先攻顺序行动，就像在战斗中一般。轮流进行回合，以确保所有人都能获得发挥的机会。尽量少用这种方式，因为这会让人感觉过于刻意，且有些时候会拖慢游戏的节奏。

Absent Players.name: 缺席玩家
Absent Players.text:
当其中一位玩家缺席时，你应该怎么处理那位玩家的角色？考虑以下选项：

淡入背景。 简单地让这位角色淡入背景。尽管需要所有人都暂时抽离游戏世界一小会儿且暂且放下不合理之处，但这可能是最简单的解决方式。当这个角色不存在一般行动，但不要尝试给出任何游戏内的解释。怪物们不会攻击这个角色，反之亦然。如果缺席者回到游戏中，玩家们会如同他的角色从未缺席一般继续游戏。

叙事技巧。 当队伍继续冒险时，你可以令这个角色在暂时身处其他地方。你也可以用一些游戏内的原因来让角色临时离开队伍，并在之后重新加入，例如他前去辟谣，或回程向队伍赞助者报告。

替补玩家。 只要缺席玩家同意，让另一位玩家运作缺席玩家的角色，或在你感觉能兼顾的前提下自己运作。无论谁运作这个角色，它都需要该角色的角色卡的副本，应努力让角色生还且明智地使用该角色的资源。

给予缺席玩家与其他玩家在每回获得的相等XP，以保持团队处于同一等级之上。

有些团队会去制定规则，规定多少位玩家缺席时无法继续游戏。例如，你的团队可能只在不超过一人缺席时继续游戏。如果两个以上的人无法参加游戏回，则考虑用不同的角色或不同的地下城主来游玩一次短程冒险，或者拿喜欢的桌游玩。

Incorporating New Players.name: 导入新玩家
Incorporating New Players.text:
当为团队引入新玩家时，重温一遍团队的期望和底线（见第 1 章内“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgEnsuringFunFo]”）。然后让新玩家创建角色，其等级与冒险队伍中其他角色的等级相同。

如果新玩家从来没有玩过D&D，且整个团队都高于 4 级，则考虑让所有人从战役中小憩片刻，并用新的1级角色玩一两个游戏回，以便新人入门。（这也是让另外的玩家轮流做DM的好机会。）

如果你在冒险的中途将新角色引入团队，先与那位角色的玩家达成合作，构思出它们的角色如何加入团队的故事引子，并确保该玩家对这个选择感到满意。以下为推荐故事情节：

失散多年的旧友。 新角色是其中一位冒险者的朋友或者亲戚。又或者，新角色与冒险者们的赞助者有关系，抑或是某个与其他角色有联系的组织的成员。无论哪种情况，这位新角色都在持续寻找着团队，或许还带着一条重要的消息。

被解救的囚犯。 新角色是其他角色们正对抗的敌人的一位囚犯。当获救时，这个角色将加入他们的团队。

唯一幸存者。 新角色是一群命运多舛的冒险者们中的唯一幸存者。新角色也许能提供线索，以免队伍重蹈其他团队的残酷命运。

特邀嘉宾

如果你想要在单次游戏回中把玩家加进团队里，也可以用导入新玩家的故事引子。例如，你可能有一位外地来的朋友，想暂时加入你的游戏。又或许你有一位正在考虑加进团队的玩家，但你想要确保它会是位不错的增加成员。偶尔引入客串的玩家是个很好的点子，这可以保留备用的玩家名单，以防你的固定玩家临时请假。

Multiple DMs.name: 多位DM
Multiple DMs.text:
Many gaming groups switch DMs from time to time. The following sections describe situations that allow for multiple DMs and ways multiple DMs can add to the group’s fun.

Occasional Breaks

Take a break from being the DM if you need to recharge your creative juices, plan out the next arc of your campaign, or finish up the adventure you’re working on. By taking a break, you create an opportunity for another player to assume the DM role for a session or two.

If not everyone can make it to a scheduled session, that can also be an opportunity for a different DM to run a short adventure.

Variety Series

Some groups don’t want a long campaign with sweeping plotlines; they prefer short, unconnected adventures. With that style of game, different players might take turns as DM for one to three sessions at a time, with each adventure standing as a self-contained story.

Concurrent Campaigns

You and the other DMs in your group can take turns running adventures for a few weeks or months at a time, with your campaign on hold during another DM’s turn. Some groups play multiple times each week, with different DMs running their campaigns on different days.

Shared World

Some groups take a large, established campaign setting and divide it up geographically so different DMs can run separate campaigns in the same setting. In theory, characters can travel from one DM’s region of the world to another’s, creating continuity in the campaign even as characters might be involved in several plotlines.

Rather than dividing a campaign geographically, you and the other DMs in your group could divide it thematically. Using @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgGreyhawk00000]{the setting} in chapter 5 of this book as an example, each DM could focus their campaign on one of the three @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgGreyhawksPrem.JournalEntryPage.EymaTb4UXmb4buZF]{overarching conflicts} of that setting. This approach allows the same group of adventurers to sink their teeth into all three overarching conflicts while ensuring that each storyline feels distinct.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh2ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.GzGny9XIDAgE3Hby caption=false classes="float-right size-two"]

Joint DMs

Two or more DMs can share the creation of a single campaign, working together to maintain continuity from session to session and making sure that each DM’s adventures advance the larger story of the world and the characters. When players who are also DMs are playing their characters, they shouldn’t let their knowledge of the campaign’s story influence their characters’ actions. Those characters step out of the action when their players take their turns as DM.

Joint DMs can also team up to run each session of a campaign, with each DM focusing on the aspects of the game they most enjoy or the DMs trading focus from session to session. One DM might run combat description and keep a battle moving while the other focuses on miniatures and music. The two DMs can play two different NPCs in a social interaction encounter. Between sessions, they can collaborate or divide up world-building, encounter creation, and other tasks.

Narration.name: 叙事
Narration.text:
使用一些久经考验的叙事技巧，可以使游戏生动有趣，让你的玩家沉浸在你的世界中。

以身作则

当你给出富有热情的扮演或叙事时，你也将为游戏增添活力，带领你的玩家们进入这个世界。鼓励玩家们描述他们角色的动作，并考虑将他们的描述纳入进他们角色的成功与失败的要素之中。

简洁

让你的描述保持简短且足以令人回味。专注在更重要的信息之中以保持玩家们的兴趣和强调重要的线索和细节。在玩家做出如何行动的决定之前，他们需要知道他们的角色所能觉察到的显著特征——尤其是房间里的怪物之类。允许你的玩家问出跟进的问题，并提供所需的额外描述。

氛围

通过润色氛围来使场景活灵活现，例如挥之不去的灰烬气味，游走在地城的地面上的小甲壳虫，或绽放在凄凉而阴郁的墓地中的蓝色花朵。选择几种感官（视觉，听觉，嗅觉，触觉，味觉）来强调氛围。

描述环境中的变化来引导玩家们的注意。例如，一只鸟在墓碑上着陆可能会将角色的注意力吸引过去。

吸引玩家注意力

好的叙述能邀请玩家去探查环境中的细节，并借此引出遭遇或重要信息。你描述的任何额外且微妙的细节都能引起玩家的注意。给予他们足够的线索来诱出更多的探索，但千万别创造出一个闪着霓虹灯的招牌，上面还写着”冒险在此“。

当使用叙事手法来引导玩家们时，记住以下几点：

区分选项。 当为玩家提供选项时，加入细节来区分这些选项。角色们应该往左还是往右？或许左边的小径闻上去有股腐朽的气息，而右边则传来微弱的潺潺流水声。这些细节给予玩家们更多细节，能让他们做出明智的决定，且不用明确告诉他们将前往何处。

不要限制选项。 通常来说，让玩家们利用给出的信息来决定他们要做什么。不要对角色的行动加以不必要的限制。话虽如此，但给出建议可能有所帮助（尤其对于新玩家们而言）。“你可以穿过那扇门，搜查箱子，或者俯视井道。”确保你在结尾时加上“或者你还想到有什么能做的事吗？”

不要假定角色的行动。 不要假定角色部分的行动。例如，不要说“你踏进了房间并向上看去”除非玩家已经告诉你他们的角色正在做什么。

秘密与发现

在探险过程中，玩家们和他们的角色们会发掘先前未知的信息。确保他们要完成冒险所需的信息是可获得的。

不要把重要的秘密或发现藏在那些角色们不大可能去探索的位置。你需要确保他们不会仅仅因为一次失败的属性检定、或是没有和正确的人交流或没找到正确的位置，而错过重要的秘密或发现。

同见本章中的“@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningExplor.JournalEntryPage.Ye1j2WmZkNtL03ee]”以获取在冒险中被隐藏的秘密的更多建议。

给单个玩家信息

当一个角色离开团队单独行动时，你可以假设该角色会在与其他队员汇合时更新信息，故而剩下的玩家了解此时发生的事。不过，你也可能需要提醒其他玩家：它们的角色并不在场，所以它们不能为独行的角色提供建议或信息。

但有些时候，你只想给特定的某名玩家提供信息：这可能是一条你认为角色不会想去分享给其余队伍的信息，或许还会连接至角色履历的元素中未公开秘密中的某处。这种情况下，你可以使用其中一种方式来传达那条信息：

隔开玩家。 拉玩家去另一房间，或者让其他玩家们离开房间。这个方式最适用于在整个场景中只有一个角色参与的情况。试着让这个场景简短些，这样其他玩家就不会觉得无聊或者感到被冷落。

秘密信息。 如果你只想传达一条简短的信息，你可以对玩家耳语，传给他们一张纸条，或给他们发短信或消息。

在聊天框中向玩家发送私聊消息

您可以通过在聊天框中输入以下内容向一名或多名玩家发送私聊消息：

/w [username 1, username 2] 您的消息内容。

Introduction.name: 简介
Introduction.text:
以 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgTheBasics0000]{第1 章} 列出的内容为基础，本章将更深入地探讨作为地下城主运行D&D游戏的方法。

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh2ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.HMSytGoRqOzPlYeQ]

What Does a DM Do?.name: DM是做什么的？
What Does a DM Do?.text:
成为DM意味着承担以下几种有趣的职能：

演员。DM操控怪物，决定它们的行动并为它们的攻击掷骰子。DM还要扮演角色们遇到的各色人物。

导演。就像电影导演一样，DM需要决定（和描述）玩家的角色们会在冒险过程中遭遇什么情景。DM还负责掌控游戏的节奏，并且营造一种引人入胜的氛围。

即兴表演者。作为DM的一大要点就是决定如何运用各项规则，并且要牢记以大家都会开心的方式来结算角色的行动。

裁判。如果规则无法对将要发生的情况做出解释，由DM来判定会发生什么事。

讲述者。DM需要创作各式各样的冒险，并将角色们置入设计好的种种情境之中，引导玩家在游戏世界中去探索、去互动。

导师。DM通常还要教导新玩家如何游玩这个游戏。

世界构建者。游戏中的冒险发生在由DM创作的世界里。即使对于现有出版物中的世界设定也是如此——你可以随心改造它。

DM贴士

要想当一名好DM，最重要的便是推动同桌之间所有人的关系融洽。以下是几个有助于游戏流畅运行的要点，请牢记：

携手共创故事。DND是个一群人在一起讲故事的游戏——而你的玩家们正是靠着角色的所言所行来推进故事。多多询问玩家的角色正在做什么，以此鼓励他们参与互动。

跑团不是竞技。DM与其玩家们并非赛场上的对手。你的任务是提供有趣的挑战，同时让故事发展。

公平且灵活。公平公正地对待你的玩家们。规则能够助你公平行事，但当规则无法给出明确规定，需要你来做出裁定时，请尽量做出让所有人都高兴的决定。

与玩家沟通。一场成功的DND游戏建立在开放而积极的沟通上。大部分问题都可以通过坦诚布公的对话来解决或避免。记得在开完团后向玩家询问问题并征集反馈。

犯错也没关系。如果你忽略或歪曲了一些事情，自己更正过来并继续吧。没有人会期待你记住所有规则或细节。即使你直到一次团结束都没有意识到你的问题，在下一次团开始时承认这个问题并继续下去，也是不错的。

2024版本有哪些新东西？

本书是五版《地下城主指南》的2024版本，其中包含了很多全新或重新设计的元素，并且本书中许多东西的版本都取代了其在旧书中的版本。以下是几条要点：

有益建议。每一章（尤其是第1、 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam]{2}、@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCreatingAdven]{4}、和 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCreatingCampa]{5}) 中都有给不同经验水平的地下城主的建议。

跟进制卡。本书中给出了许多实用的记录卡，它们可用于规划游戏并跟进战役进度。这些表单的电子版本可以在DndBeyond.com网站中下载。

遭遇构筑指南。评定战斗遭遇之难度的规则已进行了重置，详见 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgPlanEncounter.JournalEntryPage.WKL34lGhm9cZOavY#combat-encounter-difficulty]{第 4 章}。

预制要素。@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgAdventureExam]{第 4 章}中给出了数篇范例冒险、@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgGreyhawk00000]{战役设定} 在第 5 章、 附录 B中给出了 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgBMaps00000000]{新的通用地图}，这些预制要素使得你当场开团的过程更加简单。

魔法物品扩充。@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgTreasure00000]{第 7 章} 整合了新增魔法物品与重置的旧魔法物品。

据点。 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgBastions00000]{第 8 章} 给出了让玩家角色们修建、维护、享受他们自己的大本营的规则。

设定汇编。@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgALoreGlossary]{附录 A} 给出了一份实用的汇编，解释DND多元宇宙中的许多名人与胜地。

Things You Need.name: 你需要的东西
Things You Need.text:
What you need to play hasn’t changed much since the game’s first publication in 1974.

Rulebooks

As the Dungeon Master, you need this book plus the Player’s Handbook (which contains most of the rules of the game) and the Monster Manual. Your players need access to the Player’s Handbook, too, but they can share as needed.

Share Content in Foundry Virtual Tabletop

If you have the Player's Handbook module active in your world your players will all be able to access the relevant journal entries.

Let players know beforehand what books (other than the Player’s Handbook) they can reference during a playing session. For example, it’s not appropriate for players to look up a monster in the Monster Manual (or the equivalent digital tool) while fighting that monster. If you’re running a published adventure, players should avoid reading that adventure so they don’t spoil any surprises.

Monsters Coming Soon and Equipment/Spell Links

Since the Monster Manual has not been released there are many creatures that do not currently have stat blocks but are summonable using the items throughout this module. We have configured them to summon from the 2014 SRD where possible and they will be updated to use the Monster Manual versions of the creatures when it releases.

The Dungeon Master's Guide links to equipment and spells from the 2024 Player's Handbook which is required for full functionality.

A Dungeon Master

One player has the special role of Dungeon Master.

Some people love being the DM all the time, while others can end up feeling trapped as the “forever DM” for their gaming group. @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.eHLPVt8KYa7T05Di]{Group Size} section discusses possibilities for sharing the role of Dungeon Master among multiple players in a group.

Players

Players who aren’t the Dungeon Master take on the roles of the heroes, also known as the characters or the adventurers.

D&D plays best with four to six players in addition to the DM, but it’s possible to run a game with fewer or more adventurers. See the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.gMQIBEu8UdMZH1Vw]{Group Size} section for advice on doing so.

Finding Players

Where do you find players? Here are a handful of suggestions:

  • Game or hobby stores (the Store Locator on the Wizards of the Coast website can help you find stores near you that host D&D events)
  • Friends, family, community members, and work colleagues who enjoy gaming or fantasy
  • Gaming clubs at schools
  • Social media and online messaging sites
  • Gaming conventions

A Place to Play

The bare minimum of space you need to play D&D is room for everyone in your group to gather and participate.

When choosing the space you’ll be playing in, enlist your players’ help. Think about any accessibility needs you or they might have. Some players might have difficulty with low light, background music, strong odors, cramped spaces, or specific allergens. Accommodate what you can; communicate what you can’t as early as possible.

If possible, play in an area with minimal visual or auditory distractions. Favor surroundings that reinforce your desired atmosphere and have little non-player traffic. If space is shared, reserve the space in advance.

You can also play D&D anywhere you might come together in an online space, from a group video call to a sophisticated virtual tabletop.

Dice

You need a full set of polyhedral dice: d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20. It’s helpful to have at least two of each kind. Ideally, each player should also have their own set of polyhedral dice.

Lots of digital dice rollers exist. Simple, browser ­based dice rollers are easily found on the internet. Specialized dice apps can be found in app stores, and virtual tabletops typically have dice-rolling functionality built in.

Rolling Dice in Foundry VTT

Foundry includes an advanced dice rolling system. Most things will be rolled automatically from character sheets, items, or roll tables but journal entries may also contain inline rolls (e.g. [[/r 1d4]]) which can be clicked on to get a result.

Check out our Dice Rolling article to learn the rolling syntax which can be used in Macros or in the chat log.

Note-Taking Materials

Everyone needs some way to take notes. During every round of combat, someone needs to keep track of Initiative, Hit Points, conditions, and other information. Players often like to take notes about what happens in the adventure, and at least one of them should record any clues and treasure the characters collect.

Solo or Shared Journal Entries

You can create journals for each of your players to take notes in or create a shared journal which all of them can edit at the same time using Foundry's built-in collaborative editing feature.

Character Sheets

Players need some way to record important information about their characters. Plain paper works fine, but players might find official or fan-made character sheets more helpful in organizing the information. A variety of digital character sheets are also available if you’re playing online or using digital devices at the table.

Scheduling Games

Sometimes the hardest thing about running a game is finding a time when everyone can play. Some groups play for a few hours every week, while others set aside a whole day once a month. Create a schedule that works best for your group.

For new groups, it often helps to schedule a single-session game (often called a “one-shot”) as a way for people to try it out. If everyone has a great time at that one session, it can be easier to get them to make a long-term commitment.

Scheduling conflicts are sometimes inescapable. The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.eHLPVt8KYa7T05Di]{Group Size} section in chapter 2 offers some advice on what to do when a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.w8EvLUBGXjHx7Rjj]{player has to miss a session}.

Campaign Journal

Throughout this book you’ll find tracking sheets you can use to make your work as a DM easier. They range from sheets you can use to track NPCs or settlements in your game to trackers you can use to make sure you’re giving the adventurers a good number of magic items. These tracking sheets can form the basis of a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCreatingCampa.JournalEntryPage.Lr9F52qH48dMNOGA]{campaign journal}, and they’ll help you plan your adventures and build your world. You can scan or photocopy these sheets for your personal use, and you’ll find downloadable versions on DnDBeyond.com.

Useful Additions

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.1nOATvNKb9YTZjnu classes="size-three float-right"]

Various resources can enrich your game and make it more fun. Many of these resources might have digital versions, making computers, tablets, and smartphones essential elements in some D&D games and for some players.

DM Screen

A DM screen shields your books, notes, and die rolls from your players. (See the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgEnsuringFunFo.JournalEntryPage.5NXvjb1HLEYfUSf0#dm-die-rolling]{Ensuring Fun for All} section later in this chapter for more about when and why you might want to hide die rolls.) Most DM screens have art on the outward-facing panels and handy rules information on the inside-facing panels. Others might be made of fancy wood or sculpted to help set the mood for your game.

You don’t need a physical screen to hide things if you’re playing online, but it can be helpful to have ready access to important information like condition definitions, common actions, and other key rules. Some DMs set up a physical DM screen near their computer screen. A virtual tabletop might have reference information like this built in.

Adventures and Sourcebooks

Beyond the three core rulebooks, a plethora of additional content is available from Wizards of the Coast and other publishers. Adventures provide hooks, plots, maps, and encounters you can use in your game. Sourcebooks include things like new character options, new monsters, and inspiration for building your own adventures and campaigns. You can play D&D without any of these additional products, but many DMs (and players) find them to be exciting additions to the game.

Battle Grid and Miniatures

Some DMs use a battle grid and miniatures to run combat encounters, which helps players visualize scenes when playing in person. A vinyl wet-erase mat with a printed grid, a gridded whiteboard, a cutting mat, a large sheet of gridded paper, or a printed poster map—any of these can serve as a battle grid. The grid should be marked in 1-inch squares.

You also need plastic or metal miniatures to represent characters and monsters in the game, but you can use coins, extra dice, paper counters, or even pieces of candy if miniatures are unavailable.

Many software tools designed to facilitate online D&D play provide a battle grid. Even without such tools, though, many online D&D games use screen sharing in combination with drawing programs, shared whiteboards, or similar tools as simple battle grids. Some DMs are comfortable with software that allows them to control lighting and show the players exactly what they can see; others find that complex software gets in the way of the game. Use whatever works for you and your group.

Card Accessories

Some players and DMs find it helpful to have information available in the form of cards. You can buy (or make) cards with individual spells, magic items, monster stat blocks, rules reference, and similar information for easy reference.

The Basics.name: 基础
The Basics.text:
《龙与地下城》是你和你的朋友们一起扮演各种角色，共同讲述故事的一个游戏。@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbWelcomeToAdve]{ 玩家手册} 介绍了如何游玩此游戏，以及如何创建角色，即故事中的英雄；而《地下城主指南 》则是为那些主持游戏的玩家而写——教会他们如何确保所有人都玩得尽兴。这名玩家即是地下城主，又称DM。担任地下城主很有趣，也很有主导权力，还能从中获得宝贵的经验，本章将会带你串一遍基础的部分。

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.SYNOULb09ESfU2vZ]

Preparing a Session.name: 准备一次团
Preparing a Session.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.2BO45esGI5A0Rtcn classes="size-three float-right"]

The more you prepare before your game, the more smoothly the game will go—to a certain point. To avoid being either under- or overprepared, use the one-hour guideline below and prioritize what to prepare depending on the time you have available.

The One-Hour Guideline

A D&D game session usually starts with some out-of-game chatter as everyone settles down to play. Once the session gets underway, most groups can accomplish at least three things during one hour of play, where each “thing” might be any of the following:

  • Explore a location such as a chamber in a castle or a cave
  • Converse with an intelligent creature
  • Reach consensus on a divisive issue
  • Solve a tricky riddle or puzzle
  • Survive a deadly trap
  • Fight a low-difficulty combat encounter

A more difficult combat encounter might count as two or three things, and a tense negotiation can use most or all of an hour of play on its own.

Preparation Time

The following guidelines can help you prepare for a session of play using a published adventure.

One-Hour Preparation

If you spend one hour each week preparing for your game, follow these steps:

Step 1. Focus on the story of the adventure. Read or reread the adventure’s introduction and background information. Create a bulleted list of key plot points to make sure a coherent story unfolds.

Step 2. Identify the encounters you want to run, then figure out how likely it is each encounter will get played, categorizing each one as “definite,” “possible,” or “unlikely.”

Step 3. Gather any maps you’ll need for the definite and possible encounters, then focus the remainder of your prep time on the definite encounters, as outlined below.

For combat encounters, review the monsters’ tactics and stat blocks. Note any special rules that apply to the setting of the encounter.

For social interaction encounters, make notes about the nonplayer characters (NPCs) in the encounter—their personalities, goals, and tactics.

For exploration encounters, record any clues or other information the characters should learn, and review any special rules that might come into play in the encounter.

Step 4. Consider how each definite encounter relates to the players’ motivations (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.tiekOc44JRTfFZgS]{Know Your Players}). Think about elements you can add to interest them. For example, a combat encounter could open with a tense negotiation designed to appeal to players who enjoy social interaction.

Step 5. Skim the encounters you flagged as possible.

Two-Hour Preparation

With another hour to prepare, add these steps:

Step 6. Carefully review each “possible” encounter.

Step 7. Devote any time you have left to creating improvisational aids (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgResolvingOutc.JournalEntryPage.3i7ndnxVAYh4YkeH]{Improvising Answers}).

Three-Hour Preparation

If you have three hours to prepare, add these steps:

Step 8. Skim each “unlikely” encounter.

Step 9. Create a new encounter designed to appeal specifically to one player, or alter an existing encounter to relate to the goals and motivations of that player’s character. Over the course of several sessions, do this for all your players and their characters.

How to Run a Session.name: 如何带一次团
How to Run a Session.text:
本部分介绍了了如何带一次团；本书也在 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCreatingAdven]{第 4 章} 和 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCreatingCampa]{第 5 章} 详细解释了如何将回（一次团）组合成为冒险，以及如何将冒险串联成战役。

前情回顾

除了第一次以外，每回开团时都需要一段前情回顾来回想上一次团里都发生了什么。前情回顾能够帮助玩家们回忆起故事。它为上一回缺席的玩家补充了关键信息。你可以自己提供前情回顾，或者你可以让你的一位或多位玩家来进行回顾总结。每种方式都各有好处：

DM 回顾。 如果你有特定信息需要传达，或是你想要前情回顾更简明扼要并侧重于相关内容，你可以自己提供前情回顾。

玩家回顾。 如果你想知道玩家们认为重要的事情是什么，或者想了解玩家们对当前游戏的了解程度，那么你便可以让玩家们自行提供前情回顾。如果玩家们在前情回顾中漏掉了重要的细节，你可以提醒他们。

遭遇

一次D&D团大多是由一系列的遭遇组成的，如同电影由一幕幕的场景串联而成。在每个遭遇中，DM都有机会描述生物和场地，来让角色做出抉择。遭遇分为探索（与环境交互，包括谜题）、与其他生物交涉、还有战斗。 玩家手册 列出了一场遭遇中的游戏规律。下文给出了运作遭遇的三大步骤：

第 1 步：描述情景

作为DM，你有权决定向玩家披露信息都程度。所有玩家作出决策所需的信息均源自你的描述。在遵循游戏规则的前提下，同时考虑到角色的知识水平与感知能力，你应向玩家提供其所需了解的全部信息。

出版物中的冒险通常会有像这样的方块内文本——当玩家的角色首次来到这个地点、或是出现某种特定情况时，请向玩家们大声朗读这种方块内的文本。它通常是对场景的描述，这样玩家们便能知晓发生了什么，以此决定自己的角色要做什么。

无论你是在带出版物中的冒险还是自行创作的冒险，你对某一房间或情景的描述都应基于角色们能够感知到什么。你不必一次性给出事无巨细的描述——大多数玩家会在听到第三句描述时开始走神。当玩家们搜索房间时、打开抽屉和柜子、更仔细地检查东西的时候，你要给玩家更详细的描述，来说明他们的角色发现了什么。

第二章的 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningTheGam.JournalEntryPage.3E4tfiPdTc6rt1Ke]” 提供了更广泛的建议和叙述的例子。

第 2 步：鼓励玩家发言

在你完成情境描述之后，请询问玩家其角色希望采取何种行动。务必留意玩家的陈述，并确定如何妥善处理这些行动。如有必要，可进一步向玩家索取相关信息。

在某些情况下，玩家可能会给出一个集体性的回应：“我们穿过那扇门。”而在其他情况下，个别玩家可能希望执行特定的任务——例如，一名玩家可能选择搜查一个箱子，而另一名玩家则可能检查书架。在非战斗场景中，角色无需遵循轮流机制，但你需要给予每位玩家机会，让他们告知你其角色的具体行动，以便你可以处理每个角色的行为。在战斗场景中，则应按照先攻顺序依次进行。

第 3 步：描述发生了什么

在玩家描述角色的动作之后，DM的任务是在遵循游戏规则和预先设定的冒险情节的基础上，合理应对这些行动。那么，你该如何做出决策呢？请考虑以下几种可能性：

无需规则。 在某些情况下，处理场景十分简单。例如，当一名冒险者希望穿越空荡荡的房间并打开房门时，您可以直接说明门已开启，并描述门后的情景（可能需要参考您的地图和笔记）。

成功前的阻碍。 一把锁，一名守卫，或者其他的障碍可能阻碍着玩家们的能力去完成任务。此时你通常需要让玩家进行一次D20检定，尤其是属性检定。例如，打开一道锁多半需要成功通过一次敏捷（巧手）检定，而贿赂守卫则需要成功通过一次魅力（游说）检定，外加一些钱币。第 2 章的 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgResolvingOutc] 给了更多如何使用D20检定的指南，以及其他决定玩家行动结果的工具。

角色扮演。 当玩家们与其他生物交互时，请根据它们的态度（友善、冷漠或是敌对）来扮演这些生物。描述这些生物的反应时，请基于你对这些生物的了解、还有这些生物的知识与动机来即兴扮演它们，让这些生物表现得更加生动。（见第 2 章的 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningSocial.JournalEntryPage.NJf3akNxUE8vZwaE] 以了解更多）。

一次一个动作。 玩家手册 中有关动作的规则限制了角色们同一时间能干多少事情。牢记这些规则能帮助你进行裁决。

战斗。 在战斗中，很多情形都会涉及到攻击检定和豁免检定。战斗的规则可以帮助你判定角色行动的效果。第 2 章的“ @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningCombat]”一节提供了有关战斗的建议。

施法。 当一名角色施展法术时，通常可以要求该玩家说明此法术的具体功能及其处理方式。然而，若在此过程中遇到问题，则需要你亲自查阅该法术的详细描述以作出准确判断——法术的效果通常是明确阐述的。此外，玩家手册 中关于施法的通常规则，在判决法术效果时是必要参考。

特例高于规则。 通用规则掌管了游戏的每一部分，但是包括职业特性，法术，魔法物品，怪物能力以及其它元素在内的游戏也可能会与通用规则相矛盾。当特例与通则相悖时，总是特例优先。例如，通用规则说了近战武器攻击使用攻击发出者的力量调整值。但是如果某个特性说，角色可以使用魅力来发动近战武器攻击，那么此时特例凌驾于通则之上。

在叙述结果的时候，请尽量给出有趣的描述，同时也要用清晰的游戏语言来解释发生了什么。见第2章的 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningCombat.JournalEntryPage.V1W6co6loHKoxVEZ]”以了解更多。

描述的结果经常会将情景导向另一处抉择点，此时游戏流程又会回到第1步。

时间流逝

一段段情节中迭起的高潮与间歇交织应和构成了整个游戏的节奏。请参考电影是怎么展现每一幕之间的时间流逝的。当一个遭遇结束时，你便可快进到下一个——比如，几小时的旅行时间可以靠一个快速总结来省略掉（见第 2 章 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningExplor.JournalEntryPage.QrGAynDfEKmKX14L]部分以了解更多）。类似的，如果一段休息时光毫无波澜地结束，那就只需要这么告诉玩家们，并继续下一段内容——除非玩家们享受讨论诸如角色们晚餐做的什么菜，否则就不要让他们花时间讨论这类内容。略掉一些平淡的细节，尽可能快地回到行动当中来，这样也是可以的。

中场休息

当你结束一场漫长的战斗或一幕紧张的场景，又或是你需要时间去思考，那么便稍作休息一下吧。你的大脑需要时间来放松、集中精力、准备新的遭遇。如果你在考虑如何结算玩家的行动时提出休息，他们便可能会陷入疑虑之中。以此留下悬念也是可行的。

你鼓励玩家深入探讨游戏情节，精心策划行动，并开展角色间的对话和闲聊。除非玩家向您提出问题，否则您无需介入讨论。作为DM，你应善于利用这些时机稍作休息。当所有参与者准备就绪后，那就引导游戏进程继续推进。

结束这次团

请尽可能不要在遭遇还在进行时结束本次团。两次团之间的间断会打断参与者们对很多东西的记忆——例如先攻轮次还有其他一轮一轮的细节的东西。不过这种情况有一个特例：留悬念，即在故事出现重大事件或巨大变化时暂停，结束这次团。悬念可以吊住玩家的热情与兴奋，直到下一次团开始。

如果一名玩家缺席了一次团，并且你让这位玩家的角色暂时离开了队伍，那就需要确保当这名玩家回归时，他的角色也有方式回来。有些时候悬念就是为了达此这个目标的：角色英勇地冲入险境，拯救同伴于水火之中。

在一次团结束时，请给大家留几分钟，用来讨论本次团的事件。询问你的玩家们他们喜欢本次团的哪一部分，以及是否愿意见到更多此类情节。另外，请在每次团结束时记录此时发生了什么，以及当时的情况，这些笔记可以成为你备下一次团时的参考资料。

Example of Play.name: 游玩实例
Example of Play.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.3DJLdwiCSZjrle6K]

These pages present a short example of play, similar to the ones in the Player’s Handbook, to illustrate how everything outlined in the @UUID[.a7JosG8Vd7Q98yD0]{How to Run a Session} section works in practice. In this example, the Dungeon Master is running an adventure (@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgAdventureExam.JournalEntryPage.5JFl3aizjNsUlCH3]{The Fouled Stream}) from chapter 4. The four players are Amy (playing Auro, a Halfling Rogue), Maeve (playing Mirabella, an Elf Wizard), Phillip (playing Gareth, a Human Cleric), and Russell (playing Shreeve, a Goliath Fighter).

The DM starts by asking the players to recap the action of the previous session, most of which consisted of creating characters.

Jared (as DM): Last session, we met our four heroes in the little farming village of High Ery. Who remembers what happened?

Amy: We were at a village council meeting about the weird stuff in the river making the fish inedible. We volunteered to investigate.

Russell: So we set out and followed the river upstream. At the first fork, we met a treant named Borogrove who pointed us to a cave that was the source of the polluted stream.

Amy: Before he wandered off, he gave us a magic acorn, and that’s where we ended last week.

Jared: So now you’re in this gloomy forest. Dry leaves rustle under your feet. You’re still beside the stream, which looks murky and unwholesome beneath the shadowy trees. What do you want to do now?

Russell (as Shreeve): We continue upstream? (The others nod.)

Jared: OK, you make your way upstream for about another hour. The farther you go, the murkier and stinkier the water becomes. Rounding a bend, you can see a cave in the hillside ahead of you. The stream tumbles from the cave mouth. There are withered shrubs clumped around the cave, apparently poisoned by this nasty water.

Phillip (as Gareth): Into the cave!

Jared: Who’s leading the way? 1

Russell: I’ll go first.

Jared: The cave entrance is ten feet wide, with the stream running right down the middle. Do you want to go single file or two abreast? 2

Phillip: I don’t love the idea of stepping across the stream. Let’s go single file, staying on this side of the water. (Everyone else agrees.)

Jared: OK, who’s second?

Phillip: Gareth will go second.

Maeve (as Mirabella): I’ll be third in line.

Amy (as Auro): I’ll make sure nothing’s following us.

Jared: OK, Shreeve, as you reach the cave mouth, you hear the shrubs rustling.

Russell: Oh, I should’ve checked to make sure nothing was hiding in the shrubs!

Jared: In fact, the shrubs themselves are moving. They’re not rooted at all—each one has two little legs and sharp claws! Everyone, roll Initiative.

Russell: How many shrubs are attacking?

Jared: Six. Auro, what’s your Initiative? 3

Amy: I got a 14.

Russell: Shreeve goes on 5.

Maeve: A natural 20 gives me a 21!

Phillip: 19 for Gareth.

Jared: Mirabella, you’re first. What do you do?

Maeve: How many of these walking bundles of kind­ling can I get in a 15-foot Cone?

Jared: There are three on your side of the stream and three on the other side. You can get either group in your Cone. 4

Maeve: Mirabella puts her thumbs together and wiggles her fingertips. (Maeve mimics this action.) Fire shoots out from her fingers, catching the ones on our side of the stream. Burning Hands!

Jared: OK, what do I need to do? 5

Maeve: The shrub things need to make Dexterity saving throws. The DC is 14.

Jared: And how much damage do they take? 6

Maeve: (Maeve rolls 3d6 for the spell’s damage.) 13 Fire damage if they fail the save, 6 if they succeed.

Jared: Magical fire tears through them and leaves smears of ash behind! Anything else, Mirabella?

Maeve: My work here is done. (She mimes blowing smoke away from her fingertips.)

Jared: Gareth, you’re up next.

Phillip: Gareth holds his Holy Symbol and utters an imprecation while pointing at the closest shrub and casting Toll the Dead. The sound of a bell tolls, and the shrub makes a Wisdom save, DC 14.

Jared: Well, I rolled a 1.

Phillip: It takes 7 Necrotic damage!

Jared: Whatever moisture was in this “bundle of kindling” seems to dry up, and the thing keels over dead. Anything else, Gareth?

Phillip: He glares menacingly at the other shrubs.

Jared: OK, their turn. One skitters toward Mirabella!

Russell: Can I interject myself between it and Mirabella? 7

Jared: Sure, I’ll allow it. You step into the monster’s path and … (The DM makes an attack roll for the monster but rolls a 7, which isn’t going to hit.) It tears at your cloak but fails to wound you. The other one has lost any interest in fighting, and it starts running away. Now it’s Auro’s turn.

Amy: Auro looks at the one that just attacked Shreeve and pulls out his dagger. I get a 23 to hit!

Jared: That hits! What’s your damage?

Amy: Since Shreeve is next to it, I can use my Sneak Attack! The shrub takes 12 Piercing damage.

Jared: It’s felled! Mirabella, the last one is running away. Will you let it escape?

Maeve: I think Borogrove would be disappointed in us if we let it escape into the woods. I’ll cast Fire Bolt, getting a 14 to hit.

Jared: You nailed it.

Maeve: It takes 10 Fire damage!

Jared: Yeah, the last shrub is incinerated. Well done!

The DM knows something the players don’t: the withered shrubs are actually monsters. It’s important to establish which characters are closest to the hidden monsters. 1

By asking the players to choose their characters’ marching order, the DM cleverly pivots away from the withered shrubs. The players don’t realize their characters are in danger, and the DM is waiting for the right time to reveal the hidden monsters. 2

The DM rolls Initiative just once for all six monsters and writes down that they’ll go on Initiative count 17. The DM then goes around the table to get each player’s Initiative roll. See the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgRunningCombat]{Running Combat} section in chapter 2 for advice about rolling and tracking Initiative. 3

The DM doesn’t have the exact positions of the monsters mapped out on a grid, but it’s fair to assume that they’re clumped close together as they move to attack the characters. 4

It’s always fair for the DM to expect players to explain what their spells and abilities do. The DM has enough to keep track of! 5

Asking for the spell’s damage allows the DM to roll a saving throw for each monster and mark off the right amount of damage for that one. In this case, though, the monsters have Vulnerability to Fire damage (because they’re just dry shrubs) and so few Hit Points that they’ll die no matter what they roll. 6

It’s not Shreeve’s turn, but the DM decides to allow the Goliath Fighter to step in the way of the monster’s attack because it gives Shreeve a fun heroic moment. The DM changes the monster’s target to Shreeve and makes an attack roll. 7

The Rule of Fun

D&D is a game, and everyone should have fun playing it. Everyone shares equal responsibility in moving the game along, and everyone contributes to the fun when they treat each other with respect and consideration: talking through disagreements among players or their characters, and remembering that arguments or mean-spirited squabbles can get in the way of the fun.

People have many different ideas about what makes D&D fun. The “right way” to play D&D is the way you and your players agree to and enjoy. If everyone comes to the table prepared to contribute to the game, the entire table is likely to have a wonderful and memorable time.

Every DM is Unique.name: 每个DM都是独一无二的
Every DM is Unique.text:
上文中的游玩实例展示了DM如何运作遭遇，但是没有任何DM运作游戏的方式是相同的，并且也正该如此！如果你选择的游玩风格对你和你的玩家们来说颇有成效，那你就是最成功的DM。

游玩风格

以下是一些能够帮助你明确你自己的DM风格，以及你希望运作哪一类游戏的问题：

踢门还是沉浸扮演？ 游戏主要着重于战斗和行动，还是与富有细节的NPC们上演精彩的故事？

全年龄还是成人向？ 这是一个全年龄团，还是包含了成人内容的团？

写实化还是电影化？ 你是更喜欢波折的现实，还是说更喜欢让游戏更加电影化，带有英雄主义的色彩？

严肃还是轻松？ 你是想维持一个比较严肃的团风，还是更倾向于营造幽默的氛围？

事先备团还是即兴口胡？ 你喜欢仔细准备还是更偏向于即兴发挥？

面面俱到还是专一主题？ 游戏是混合了多种主题风格，还是聚焦于单一主题风格——比如恐怖内容？

灵活道德还是英雄主义？ 你是否接受具有灵活道德底线的角色们？例如，你是否允许角色们为达最终目的而不择手段？还是说，你更喜欢直截了当的英雄行为，例如公平、牺牲、奉献以及帮助受压迫者？

房规

房规，即是你在自己桌中自用的全新规则或对现有规则的改动，用来改进你心目中游戏的方式。在你设置房规前，问自己以下两个问题：

  • 这些规则或改动能改善游戏吗？
  • 我的玩家会喜欢吗？

如果你确定两个问题的答案都是“对”，那么就尝试一下新写的规则吧。使用房规本身亦是一种试验，你需要让你的玩家给出对房规的反馈。如果他们觉得某条房规不好玩，那就得抛弃或改进它。

记录规则判例

如果在游戏中出现了对某个规则解释的疑问，那就记录下你是如如何判定的。你可以将这些判例收入你的房规合集中，这样你和玩家们就能于再次遇到此类规则时进行参考。

氛围

一些DM使用音乐来为每回游戏营造恰当的氛围感。这样的DM们通常使用来自于冒险电影或游戏中的原音，不过诸如古典音乐、背景音或其他此类音乐亦是很好用的。

一些DM会通过调节光亮与使用音效来塑造氛围。微缩模型和实物模型也对增进游戏氛围和帮助玩家可视化行动很有帮助。不过这么做之前最好先与玩家进行沟通：一些人可能觉得音乐、光源、音效会让人分心；也可能有人不想被巨大的声音吓到，或者需要避开某些特定的光效。

分摊任务

如果你不希望亲自处理游戏中的某些内容，可以将其委托给团队中的其他玩家。例如，如果你担心查阅规则会中断叙事流程，可以指派一名玩家担任规则顾问。同样地，如果你不愿意负责追踪先攻顺序，也可以将此任务交由玩家执行。

旁观学习

学习如何带D&D团的最好方式之一，便是旁观正在开团的DM。旁观其他DM能助你清晰理解DM这一身份的职责，也能让你收获能加入自己的团里的炫酷灵感。

旁观其它DM的团时，你可以着重关注下列几道问题：

每场开篇。 DM的每一回团是如何开场的？有前情回顾吗？

肢体语言。 DM在描述场景时使用了什么样的姿势？DM的肢体语言在扮演不同NPC时是如何变化的？

DM的声音。 DM给不同NPC使用不同声音或说话习惯了吗？DM在不同场合改变叙述时的声音大小和快慢了吗？

玩家参与度。 玩家有参与构建世界、或是做出可能会让冒险进入未知领域的决定了吗？

规则裁定。 DM在裁定结果时有多大程度依赖规则？DM是明智裁定规则，还是按节目效果来裁定规则？

三大支柱。 战斗、探索、社交，分别占了每场游戏的多大比重？

团风和气氛。 你会如何描述这场游戏的团风和气氛？它在一场游戏之中有没有发生过改变？

Introduction.name: 简介
Introduction.text:
冒险者们会为了许多事物而奋战，包括但不限于荣誉、知识与正义。但有的冒险者会更青睐一些具体的东西——宝藏。本章将会展示从钱币至魔法物品所有形式的宝藏。

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgCh7ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.G2g8KjUZGQTEj1Qf]

Treasure Themes.name: 宝藏主题
Treasure Themes.text:
正如怪物图鉴中所述，怪物们有着属于自己的宝藏偏好。这些偏好将会表现为“主题”，如宝藏主题表中所总结的那样，这可以帮助你决定角色们在怪物的宝库中找到了怎样的宝藏。

有关如何在冒险中安放宝藏的建议，见第4章 “@UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgAdventureRewa]{冒险奖励}”。

如果要随机决定作为宝藏发现的魔法物品，请使用本章末尾的表格。

宝藏主题

主题

对应宝藏

奥秘

宝石以及超自然或充盈魔能的魔法物品

武备

钱币或贸易金条以及在战中很有用的魔法物品

器具

钱币、贸易金条或商业货物以及侧重于实用性的魔法物品

圣物

艺术品以及具有宗教起源或归宿的魔法物品

Coins.name: 钱币
Coins.text: 最经典的宝藏类型便是金钱了，它们包括铜币（CP）、银币（SP）、金银币（EP）、金币（GP）以及铂金币（PP）。见 玩家手册 以了解它们的相对价值，每五十枚任意类型的钱币合一磅重。

Trade Bars.name: 贸易金属条
Trade Bars.text:
由于大量的钱币难以运输与清点，因此有许多商人更喜爱贸易金属条——一种用贵金属合金（通常是银）铸成的锭。这些金条以重量计价，并在贸易金属条表中有所展示。

Gemstones.name: 宝石
Gemstones.text:
与同等价值的钱币相比，宝石体积更小，重量更轻，携带更安全。

若宝藏中包含宝石，你可以根据下表基于宝石的价值随机决定发现的宝石类型。你可以投掷一次并假设所有宝石均为同种，也可以多次投掷以创造一套混合的宝石藏品。

Art Objects.name: 艺术品
Art Objects.text:
纯金铸造的偶像，珠光宝气的项链，古代国王的肖像，镶满金玉的餐盘——艺术品包含这些所有，乃至更多。

若一份宝藏中包含艺术品，你可以根据下表基于艺术品的价值随机决定发现的艺术品类型。根据宝藏库中艺术品的数量，多次依照表格进行掷骰。同一件艺术品可能会重复出现。
